H0.text: Increased fish populations are the most likely result of large‑scale agricultural fertilization on aquatic systems.

H1.text: More biodiversity over time is the most likely result of large-scale agricultural fertilization on aquatic systems.

H2.text: Less oxygen available for fish is the most likely result of large‑scale agricultural fertilization on aquatic systems.

H3.text: Reduced water levels are the most likely result of large‑scale agricultural fertilization on aquatic systems.

A4.text: Increased competition for the added nutrients can cause potential disruption to entire ecosystems and food webs, as well as a loss of habitat, and biodiversity of species.

A6.text: The process of the oversupply of nutrients leading to algae growth and oxygen depletion is called eutrophication.

A7.text: This can result in a sharp decrease in available dissolved oxygen for other aquatic life.
